awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Illuminating heme trafficking and signaling for research and education
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of this project are (i) to understand how cells manage and utilize heme, an essential but toxic nutrient, and (ii) to educate, train, and diversify a new generation of scientists. Heme is required by much of life, enabling a vast number of proteins and cellular processes to function properly. However, heme is also known to promote cellular dysfunction due to its toxic properties. How do cells and organisms utilize heme while mitigating its toxicity? The PI proposes that there are distinct molecules that help shuttle heme to different locations in a controlled manner and various physiological stimuli can initiate heme mobilization. Using heme sensors recently developed in the PI's laboratory, graduate, undergraduate, and high school/middle school students will collaborate to determine how cellular heme is handled and mobilized throughout the cell. This research will not only reveal the manner by which cells manage an "essential toxin" like heme, but also provide new tools and methodologies that will benefit the large community of scientists that study heme. Moreover, the research will be used as a vehicle to promote participation of under-represented minorities in science. A long-term scientific mentorship program will be developed in which Hispanic middle school students from metro-Atlanta will work with the PI's group to implement the research. 

Heme is well known as an essential iron containing cofactor. A number of heme regulated factors and processes are conserved from yeast to man, suggesting a role for heme as a dynamic signaling molecule. This project aims to reimagine and expand the role of heme in cell biology as a signaling molecule. The cytotoxicity and hydrophobicity of heme requires that it be trafficked in a highly coordinated manner from its site of synthesis in the mitochondria to hemoproteins present in every subcellular compartment, including the nucleus. However, the molecules and mechanisms that mediate the initiation, transmission, and integration of heme-based signals and the spatio-temporal dynamics of heme mobilization for trafficking and signaling are unknown. This is in large part due to the lack of tools available to image labile heme pools relevant to trafficking and signaling. The PI's group has recently overcome this major technological barrier by generating genetically encoded ratiometric fluorescent heme sensors. The project will utilize these heme sensors in conjunction with mass spectrometry based proteomics and yeast molecular genetics to delineate the molecules and mechanisms that mediate heme trafficking and signaling and their dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Heme, the pigment that gives blood its bright red color, is an essential iron containing metabolite required for virtually all life on Earth. The essentiality of heme stems from its role as a cofactor, or helper molecule, that enables a vast number of proteins and cellular processes to function properly. Moreover, there are emerging roles for heme as a key signaling molecule that allows cells to dynamically respond to their environment or changing metabolic needs. Rather ironically, despite being absolutely required, heme can also be toxic. Thus, cells are challenged to tightly control heme concentration and bioavailability. How cells manage heme is not understood. Indeed, various environmental toxins, infectious diseases, certain genetic disorders, and aging can all lead to defects in cellular and organismal heme homeostasis, which in turn leads to additional dysfunction. How do cells safely transport and traffic heme from sites of synthesis or uptake to heme-dependent or -regulated proteins? What are the molecules and mechanisms that mediate the initiation, transmission, and integration of heme-based signals and the spatial and temporal dynamics of heme mobilization for trafficking and signaling? Answers to these questions will reveal the fundamental rules that govern heme management and utilization and inspire new heme-based therapies to treat diseases associated with defects in heme metabolism.

In this NSF-funded research program we developed and applied fluorescence- and activity-based heme biosensors and proteomics approaches to probe the dynamics of heme mobilization and identify factors that transport and traffic heme in various model cell lines, including yeast, human cell lines, and in human pathogens. Our work revealed that many enzymes and proteins moonlight as heme buffering and trafficking factors and that contact sites between organelles mediate heme distribution. We also discovered several new proteins that are dynamically regulated by heme, revealing for the first time the presence of expansive heme signaling networks. Moreover, we found that well known signaling molecules like nitric oxide and hydrogen peroxide, or heavy metal toxicants like lead, can dynamically mobilize and redistribute subcellular heme pools, leading to both positive and negative effects on cell physiology due to altered heme signaling. Additionally, our work found that the source of heme, whether it is made by the cell or scavenged from nutritional sources, substantially affects its subcellular distribution. Altogether, our work has revealed unprecedented new insights into heme cell biology.

All the research activities conducted were used as a vehicle to promote and increase participation of traditionally under-represented people in science. We developed a long-term scientific mentorship program in which a small group of Hispanic middle school students (4-6) from metro-Atlanta worked with the research team every summer for 5 years until they graduated high school. The research-related tasks increased in complexity as the students matured and grew up. Moreover, working with the teachers that chaperoned the student visits, we were able to develop mini lessons plans for middle and high school students based on the research our lab conducted. Thus, in total, we were able to successfully use our research to broaden participation in the scientific endeavor to great effect.
